text: Tenju (天授) was a Japanese era name (年号, nengō, lit. year name) of the Southern Court during the Nanboku-chō period after Bunchū and before Kōwa. This period started in May 1375 and ended in February 1381.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Tenju" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 959. The Southern Court monarch in Yoshino during this time was .Nussbaum, "Chōkei Tennō," p. 120. The Northern Court pretender in Kyoto was .Nussbaum, "Go-En'yū Tennō," p. 251; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 310-312. ==Events of the Tenju era == * 1375 (Tenju 1): Shogun Ashikaga Yoshimitsu visits Iwashimizu Hachiman-gū.Titsingh, p. 312. * 1377 (Tenju 3): Goryeo diplomatic envoy Jeong Mongju met with the in Kyūshū, Imagawa Ryōshun. The diplomats discussed steps to control pirates (wakō).Titsingh, p. 313; Kang, Jae-eun et al. (2006). The Land of Scholars : Two Thousand Years of Korean Confucianism, p. 159. * 1378 (Tenju 4): Yoshimitsu moved into his new home in Muromachi;Titsingh, p. 313. and the luxurious house and grounds are called Hana-no-GoshoAckroyd, Joyce. (1982) Lessons from History: The "Tokushi Yoron", p. 329. * 26 July 1380 (Tenju 6, 24th day of the 6th month): Former pretender Kōmyō died at age 60.Titsingh, p. 315. ==Northern Court nengō== * Eiwa, 1375–1379 * Kōryaku, 1379–1381 ==Related pages== * Muromachi period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Tenju 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 1375 1376 1377 1378 1379 1380 1381 Preceded by: Bunchū Era or nengō: Tenju Succeeded by: Kōwa Category:Japanese eras Category:1370s establishments in Japan Category:1380s disestablishments in Japan
